docs.text: A guide on how to save time in capturing timesheets with the assistance of Time Tracker Introduction ¶ Consider these questions: Did I start my day at 7:30 AM or 7:45 AM? Did I spend 15 minutes or 45 minutes looking at a support ticket? How long was I out for my lunch break? Am I working too many hours or too few hours? When I forget to complete my timesheet every day, how do I figure out what I did? If you answered yes to any of the above questions, and you work on a computer most of the day, then Time Tracker is the answer all of the above questions. Installing Time Tracker ¶ There currently isn't an installer for the tool. Take the TimeTracker.Windows.1.3.5.zip and extract it anywhere on your computer. Start the application by running the TimeTrackerService.bat file. By default, the application isn't set to auto start. You can turn on this functionality in Global Settings (the Auto Start Application option) to add Time Tracker to your startup applications. Note that once the backend service has started you'll need to open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:8093 tag time. Even if the browser isn't open the tool will continue to operate in the background To get started with using the tool have a look at the Capture Screen
docs.title: Welcome

docs.title: Installing Time Tracker

docs.text: Introduction ¶ Auto Capture allows the tool to automatically capture the time if the window name or application name matches the provided filters. The window name and application name are case-insensitive and check if the filter contains the provided text. For example, if I filter "Outlook" for the window name window name, it would match "Microsoft Outlook", "Mail - Outlook", etc. Then you can select which client, project, activity, ticket number, description where this time will be auto-captured
docs.title: Auto Capture

docs.text: Auto Capture allows the tool to automatically capture the time if the window name or application name matches the provided filters. The window name and application name are case-insensitive and check if the filter contains the provided text. For example, if I filter "Outlook" for the window name window name, it would match "Microsoft Outlook", "Mail - Outlook", etc. Then you can select which client, project, activity, ticket number, description where this time will be auto-captured
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Introduction ¶ Time Tracker tracks the duration of the currently focused window title and application path. Every time you focus on a new window, Time Tracker takes a screenshot and captures the new window title and application path. After using the tool for a few hours, it's easy to find out what you've been doing all day. To track time, hover over the Start area until you find the time you want to track and click the item you want to track. Next, hover over the time in the End capture area and click the end of the activity for which you want to capture time. Tip Use the screenshots to see what you have done. Now that you have selected the start and end time for the activity, either click the Allocate Time button or select any area in the Capture line. Fill in what you did during this period. In my case, I worked on the documentation for this tool. When you are finished, click the Save button. Now that you have allocated your time, it will appear in blue on the capture line. Tip You can record additional time to any time you have previously recorded by simply selecting a new Start and End time and then selecting the blue capture line. of an existing client/project/activity. Tip You can search for any part of the application path, window title, client name, project name or activity name using the global search box in the top right-hand corner. When you are done for the day you can easily see what activities you have spent your day on by simply clicking on the Summary button. You can adjust the application settings by selecting the Global Settings button. Sometimes you may have some items you want to captur, such as a password spreadsheet, or a sensitive email. To exclude screenshots for specific applications or windows simply add an exclusion by clicking on the Exclusions button. Do you have daily repetitive tasks such as answering emails, checking on ticket statuses etc? To simplify this process you can set up automatic tagging by using the Auto Capture button.
docs.title: Capture Screen

docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Introduction ¶ Exclusions allow the tool to exclude certain applications or window titles from being logged or prevent screenshots from being taken. Exclusions are case-insensitive and check if the filter contains the provided text. E.g. if I select the filter "team" for Window Name, this would match, "Microsoft Teams", "Team Foundation Server", "Team Fortress". I can then choose to hide the screenshot, the window name and/or the application name.
docs.title: Exclusions

docs.text: Exclusions allow the tool to exclude certain applications or window titles from being logged or prevent screenshots from being taken. Exclusions are case-insensitive and check if the filter contains the provided text. E.g. if I select the filter "team" for Window Name, this would match, "Microsoft Teams", "Team Foundation Server", "Team Fortress". I can then choose to hide the screenshot, the window name and/or the application name.
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Where is Time Tracker's data stored on my machine? ¶ Navigate to C:\Users\fill-in-your-user-name-here\AppData\Local\TimeTracker in File Explorer logs - the application error logs used for diagnosing issues Screenshots - folder has the screenshots taken by the application divided by day. time-tracker.db - the SQLLite database storing all previously tracked time Tip quite large How to I backup Time Tracker's data as I'm changing to a new PC ¶ See the section where Time Tracker is storing its data. Copy or zip the contents of the folder to your backup medium. Then simply create the TimeTracker folder in the **\AppData\Local** folder on your new computer and start Time Tracker I would like to Sync my Time Tracker data between multiple machines. How would I go about that? ¶ Unfortunately Time Tracker does not have any networking capabilities at present. If this is a very common requirement then I will consider building in this functionality in future
docs.title: FAQ

docs.text: Navigate to C:\Users\fill-in-your-user-name-here\AppData\Local\TimeTracker in File Explorer logs - the application error logs used for diagnosing issues Screenshots - folder has the screenshots taken by the application divided by day. time-tracker.db - the SQLLite database storing all previously tracked time Tip quite large
docs.title: Where is Time Tracker's data stored on my machine?

docs.text: See the section where Time Tracker is storing its data. Copy or zip the contents of the folder to your backup medium. Then simply create the TimeTracker folder in the **\AppData\Local** folder on your new computer and start Time Tracker
docs.title: How to I backup Time Tracker's data as I'm changing to a new PC

docs.title: I would like to Sync my Time Tracker data between multiple machines. How would I go about that?

docs.text: Introduction ¶ Click on the Global Settings button to change the global settings for the tool. Screen Poll Interval (In Minutes) - the time between polling for screen changes. e.g. if I selected 3 minutes then the tool would only check for active window changes every 3 minutes. Idle Time Threshold (In Minutes) - the number of minutes before marking time as idle No Activity Threshold (In Minutes) - the number of minutes before detecting that the computer/laptop was off Auto Start Application - Launch tool automatically when your user logs in Remember to select the Save button for your changes to take effect. Warning If you enable "Auto Start Application" but you disable the application in the Startup Apps in Windows Settings then Time Tracker will obey the windows settings and not start up.
docs.title: Global Settings

docs.text: Click on the Global Settings button to change the global settings for the tool. Screen Poll Interval (In Minutes) - the time between polling for screen changes. e.g. if I selected 3 minutes then the tool would only check for active window changes every 3 minutes. Idle Time Threshold (In Minutes) - the number of minutes before marking time as idle No Activity Threshold (In Minutes) - the number of minutes before detecting that the computer/laptop was off Auto Start Application - Launch tool automatically when your user logs in Remember to select the Save button for your changes to take effect. Warning If you enable "Auto Start Application" but you disable the application in the Startup Apps in Windows Settings then Time Tracker will obey the windows settings and not start up.
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: Introduction ¶ The Summary screen shows you all the activities you achieved for your day rounded off to the nearest 15 minutes. If you repeated the same activity again later in the day, the time is combined as one. Using the summary screen, you can very easily see how much time you spent on completing your tasks for completing your daily timesheets. Monthly Summary ¶ If you would like to see which projects you worked on for the entire month. Simply select the Month Summary button. You can adjust the start and end day for the "Month Summary" by changing the Start and End dates. So you can easily see what you did for the last week, month, year, etc.
docs.title: Day Summary

docs.title: Monthly Summary
